enrich_metadata.label: San Francisco
enrich_metadata.abstract: San Francisco (/sæn frənˈsɪskoʊ/), officially the City and County of San Francisco, is the cultural, commercial, and financial center of Northern California and the only consolidated city-county in California. San Francisco encompasses a land area of about 46.9 square miles (121 km2) on the northern end of the San Francisco Peninsula, which makes it the smallest county in the state. It has a density of about 18,187 people per square mile (7,022 people per km2), making it the most densely settled large city (population greater than 200,000) in the state of California and the second-most densely populated major city in the United States after New York City. San Francisco is the fourth-most populous city in California, after Los Angeles, San Diego and San Jose, and the 13th-most populous city in the United States—with a Census-estimated 2014 population of 852,469. The city and its surrounding areas are known as the San Francisco Bay Area, and are a part of the larger OMB designated San Jose-San Francisco-Oakland combined statistical area, the fifth most populous in the nation with an estimated population of 8.6 million. San Francisco (Spanish for Saint Francis) was founded on June 29, 1776, when colonists from Spain established Presidio of San Francisco at the Golden Gate and Mission San Francisco de Asís named for St. Francis of Assisi a few miles away. The California Gold Rush of 1849 brought rapid growth, making it the largest city on the West Coast at the time. San Francisco became a consolidated city-county in 1856.After three-quarters of the city was destroyed by the 1906 earthquake and fire, San Francisco was quickly rebuilt, hosting the Panama-Pacific International Exposition nine years later. In World War II, San Francisco was the port of embarkation for service members shipping out to the Pacific Theater. After the war, the confluence of returning servicemen, massive immigration, liberalizing attitudes, along with the rise of the "hippie" counterculture, the Sexual Revolution, the Peace Movement growing from opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War, and other factors led to the Summer of Love and the gay rights movement, cementing San Francisco as a center of liberal activism in the United States. Politically, the city votes strongly along liberal Democratic Party lines. San Francisco is a popular tourist destination, known for its cool summers, fog, steep rolling hills, eclectic mix of architecture, and landmarks including the Golden Gate Bridge, cable cars, the former Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary, Fisherman's Wharf, and its Chinatown district. San Francisco is also the headquarters of five major banking institutions and various other companies such as Levi Strauss & Co., Gap Inc., Salesforce.com, Dropbox, Reddit, Square, Inc., Dolby, Airbnb, Weebly, Pacific Gas and Electric Company, Yelp, Pinterest, Twitter, Uber, Mozilla, Wikimedia Foundation, and Craigslist. It has several nicknames, including "The City by the Bay", "Fog City", "San Fran", and "Frisco", as well as older ones like "The City that Knows How", "Baghdad by the Bay", and "The Paris of the West". As of 2015, San Francisco was ranked high on world livability rankings.

attraction_reviewComments: We went on a tour around Hollywood Hills. The properties are beautiful but very secluded by trees or gates or just too far from the road. Several stars homes were pointed out in... read more
On a clear day, the Hollywoid Hills give views of city all the way to the ocean. Its seems as if everytime I go, the smog pollution is worse and worse. I guess the price you have... read more
We bought a bus to show us the place, the houses and everything and it was really exciting. But, the told us that they would make us go to Justin Bieber's House but he doesn't... read more
This was fantastic, worth the trip we went in a sports car tour, worth while was not expensive and we did cover a lot of ground. Driving up some great steep streets and seeing... read more
We took a drive through the Hollywood Hills and it was beautiful. There were gorgeous homes and some of the views were amazing. Definitely worth driving through.
Thought it would be cool to spend some time exploring the maze of roads and really glad we did. Amazing houses and lots of inspiration to take back home for some DIY. The right... read more
This is the place to spot for super stars or your favorite stars home and if you're lucky enough you might even see them. Open your eyes to spot them.
Don't get lost, but definitely go for a drive through the hills all the way to the top. Where a lot of the stars live, and where a lot of the craziest times in LA have happened... read more
Did the guided tour ... Well worth it ... Enjoyed the local knowledge and wouldn't have been able to do it on our own.
We did the Mulholland Drive rride from the vicinity of the Hollywood Bowl over to Laurel Canyon .The ride was very enjoyable .The scenery is vantastic .We had previously taken a... read more
Fun to get lost, find your way. Discover amazing large and tiny homes.
Amazing views and scenery, but the locals drive recklessly on the slim roads that allow only one car to drive through w the steep hills and sharp curves you can't see whats coming... read more
Ok, yes I was being a tourist with my "map" of the stars homes-probably outdated. Still nice to drive the roads, check out the homes. We took it up to Mulholland Drive (not sure... read more
If you have extra time while in L.A. Take your car into the Hollywood hills the roads are very narrow but the views are spectacular and the homes run the gambit from small to... read more
I'm an architect and the Hollywood Hills are excellent to see how the mid-level of the entertainment industry lives. Some of the houses are very dumpy and tired looking 60s... read more
This area you must visit on a sunny day - nice area with some spectular buildings owned by the movie stars and singers.
Amazing views and scenery, the houses are truly breath taking. Just a short drive from the hustle & bustle of Hollywood.
Nice tour around movie star neighborhood. Awesome views make it even funnier. If you feel like you need to watch and stalk celebrities then that's your place to visit!
This is a must see on a tour. Interesting to hear the history and lifestyles in the Hills. Good views of the area. Drive along Mullholland and other streets gave a lot of... read more
You have to see the Hills if you are in Hollywood. You would have missed out on what the "other side" live like.
Great view of the city. Roads were little curvy but worth the drive. Great tour of the homes of the rich and famous.
This drive was an amazing experience. I would highly recommend it for scenic views and a fun relaxing day, especially if you like driving. We rented a convertible so it was... read more
Unless you're a local, you should do touring the Hollywood hills as a drive, not a walk, because it's steep & directions are a bit crazy - GPS is very useful. The winding streets... read more
Interesting to drive through here, but you certainly can't stop and admire the view from up here very easily. Traffic now is unending. I don't know how the residents stand the... read more
The Hollywood Sign is what you think of, when you think about LA. I was not disappointed, we saw it via the Holllywood Boulevard. If you go onto the third floor you can get... read more
All the reviews talk about driving through the hills. Either the driver isn't enjoying the sights or he is endangering others. Get out of those cars, people!

enrich_metadata.abstract: San Rafael (/ˌsæn rəˈfɛl/ SAN rə-FEL; [san rafaˈel]) (Spanish for "Saint Raphael") is a city and the county seat of Marin County, California, United States. The city is located in the North Bay region of the San Francisco Bay Area. As of the 2010 census the city's population is 57,713.

The city is located in the North Bay region of the San Francisco Bay Area. As of the 2010 census the city's population is 57,713.

enrich_metadata.label: San Juan Capistrano, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: San Juan Capistrano (/sæn ˌwɑːn kæpᵻˈstrɑːnoʊ/; [saŋ ˈxwaŋ kapisˈtɾano]) is a city in Orange County, California, United States. The current OMB metropolitan designation for San Juan Capistrano and the Orange County Area is "Santa Ana-Anaheim-Irvine, CA." The population was 34,593 at the 2010 census, up from 33,826 at the 2000 census. The city was created around Mission San Juan Capistrano, and many of the homes and strip malls resemble the Spanish architecture that composes the building. It is home to the widest variety of homes in Orange County, including those built prior to 1900 in its central district (some being adobes from the 18th century). San Juan Capistrano formerly hosted a population of cliff swallows that migrate each year from Argentina to the Mission San Juan Capistrano.

attraction_reviewComments: Wonderful views of the ocean, cliffs, rocks, distant mountains. However, why not park the car and walk on the boardwalk or the beach? The boardwalk is well maintained, there are... read more
Walk the wooden trail and meander onto the beach to see the tidepools and wildlife. You may even be lucky enough to see a sealion, whale or otter family. The view of the Pacific... read more
This is a wonderful easy walk along the coast, flat, handicapped accessible, dog friendly (on leash).
I loved walking along Moostone Drive - walkways to beach, a park to sit and enjoy the ocean or have lunch and watch the wildlife and the sealife.
A meandering boardwalk with benches to sit on from time to time and a fun time looking for moonstones on the beach. Enjoyed the park at the north end of Moonstone Drive. Picnic... read more
Walk the boardwalk and watch the sun gone down or just sit and do nothing.. Great place.
This is a great area with many small hotels and a couple of restaurants. The boardwalk is really nice and accessibility is not an issue. It is above the beach which is down the... read more
Early morning walks or better the long walk during sunsets is incredible. Wooden walkways and many benches to sit awhile to enjoy the views.
Ahh, the air, the sunsets, the early morning walks, the boardwalk, the waves crashing against the rocks. Ahhhh. Pure joy
We always stay at the Sand Pebbles Inn because it is on Moonstone Drive right across from the ocean. I love to walk on the boardwalk and listen to the waves at night.
We loved walking along with boardwalk. It is well maintained and covers a long path on the cliffs above the beautiful beach. The views are fantastic. We saw many seabirds, as well... read more
I hope to one day return and spend some days to explore this area more.
Moonstone Drive is one of our favorite places to walk. It is a beautiful walk along a path overlooking the ocean. Breathtaking!

enrich_metadata.label: Civic Center, Bakersfield
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Bakersfield, Kern County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Civic Center is a district in Downtown Bakersfield, California. It is the center of government for the City of Bakersfield and the County of Kern, containing a collection of buildings used by the city, county, state, and federal governments. The district also contains all of downtown's sporting complexes. It also has the Rabobank Theater and Convention Center, which is the largest theater and convention facilities in the city.

enrich_metadata.label: Nevada City, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Nevada City (originally, Ustumah, a Nisenan Maidu village; later, Nevada, Deer Creek Dry Diggins, and Caldwell's Upper Store) is the county seat of Nevada County, California, United States, located 60 miles (97 km) northeast of Sacramento and 28 miles north of Auburn. In 1900, 3,250 people lived in Nevada City; in 1910, 2,689 lived there; at the 2000 census, the population was 3,001, and at the 2010 census it was 3,068.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Nevada_City,_California

enrich_metadata.comment: Nevada City (originally, Ustumah, a Nisenan Maidu village; later, Nevada, Deer Creek Dry Diggins, and Caldwell's Upper Store) is the county seat of Nevada County, California, United States, located 60 miles (97 km) northeast of Sacramento and 28 miles north of Auburn. In 1900, 3,250 people lived in Nevada City; in 1910, 2,689 lived there; at the 2000 census, the population was 3,001, and at the 2010 census it was 3,068.

enrich_metadata.label: Tracy, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Tracy is the second most populated city in San Joaquin County, California, United States. The population was 82,922 at the 2010 census. Tracy is located inside a geographic triangle formed by Interstate 205 on the north side of the city, Interstate 5 to the east, and Interstate 580 to the southwest; this has given rise to Tracy's motto, now recorded on the city's website: "Think Inside the Triangle".

enrich_metadata.label: Dana Point, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Dana Point, Orange County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Dana Point is a city located in southern Orange County, California. The population was 33,351 at the 2010 census. It has one of the few harbors along the Orange County coast, and with ready access via State Route 1, it is a popular local destination for surfing. The city was named after the headland of Dana Point, which was in turn named after Richard Henry Dana, Jr., author of Two Years Before the Mast, which included a description of the area. Dana described the locale, including neighboring San Juan Capistrano, as "the only romantic spot on the coast". Although Dana described the anchorage as poor, it is now a developed harbor and contains a replica of his ship, the Pilgrim. The Pilgrim is used as a classroom by the Ocean Institute, which is located at the harbor. This area is designated California Historical Landmark #189.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Dana_Point,_California
enrich_metadata.comment: Dana Point is a city located in southern Orange County, California. The population was 33,351 at the 2010 census. It has one of the few harbors along the Orange County coast, and with ready access via State Route 1, it is a popular local destination for surfing.

enrich_metadata.label: Beverly Hills, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Beverly Hills is a city in Los Angeles County, California, United States, surrounded by the cities of Los Angeles and West Hollywood. Originally a Spanish ranch where lima beans were grown, Beverly Hills was incorporated in 1914 by a group of investors who had failed to find oil, but found water instead and eventually decided to develop it into a town. By 2013, its population had grown to 34,658. Sometimes referred to as "90210", one of its primary ZIP codes, it is home to many actors and celebrities. The city includes the Rodeo Drive shopping district and the Beverly Hills Oil Field.

enrich_metadata.label: Sunnyvale, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Sunnyvale, Santa Clara County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Sunnyvale (/ˈsʌniveɪl/ or /ˈsʌnivəl/) is a city located in Santa Clara County, California. As of the 2010 United States Census, the population was 140,095. The city is one of the major cities that make up Silicon Valley. It is the seventh most populous city in the San Francisco Bay Area. Sunnyvale is bordered by portions of San Jose to the north, Moffett Federal Airfield to the northwest, Mountain View to the west, Los Altos to the southwest, Cupertino to the south, and Santa Clara to the east. It lies along the historic El Camino Real and Highway 101. As part of California's high-tech area known as Silicon Valley, companies such as Juniper Networks, Fortinet, Advanced Micro Devices, NetApp, Spansion, Yahoo!, AppliedMicro and Ariba are headquartered there. Sunnyvale is also home to several aerospace/defense companies; Lockheed Martin has a major facility in Sunnyvale, and Honeywell, Northrop Grumman Electronic Systems - Marine Systems (formerly Joshua Hendy Iron Works), Finisar, and Spirent also have offices in Sunnyvale. Sunnyvale was also the home to Onizuka Air Force Station, often referred to as "the Blue Cube" due to the color and shape of its windowless main building. The facility, previously known as Sunnyvale Air Force Station, was named for the deceased Space Shuttle Challenger astronaut Ellison Onizuka. It served as an artificial satellite control facility of the United States armed forces until August 2010 and has since been decommissioned and demolished. Sunnyvale is one of the few U.S. cities to have a single unified Department of Public Safety, where all personnel are trained as firefighters, police officers, and EMTs, so they can respond to an emergency in any of the three roles. Library services for the city are provided by the Sunnyvale Public Library, located at the Sunnyvale Civic Center.

enrich_metadata.label: Riverside, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Riverside, Riverside County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Riverside is a city in Riverside County, California, United States, located in the Inland Empire metropolitan area. Riverside is the county seat of the eponymous county and named for its location beside the Santa Ana River. It is the most populous city in the Inland Empire as well as Riverside County, and is located approximately 60 miles (97 km) east of Los Angeles. It is also part of the Greater Los Angeles area. Riverside is the 59th most populous city in the United States and 12th most populous city in California. As of the 2010 Census, Riverside had a population of 303,871. Riverside was founded in the early 1870s and is the birthplace of the California citrus industry as well as home of the Mission Inn, the largest Mission Revival Style building in the United States. It is also home to the Riverside National Cemetery. The University of California, Riverside, is located in the northeastern part of the city. The university also hosts the Riverside Sports Complex. Other attractions in Riverside include the Fox Performing Arts Center, Riverside Metropolitan Museum, which houses exhibits and artifacts of local history, the California Museum of Photography, the California Citrus State Historic Park, and the Parent Washington Navel Orange Tree, the last of the two original navel orange trees in California.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Riverside,_California
